qas.question: When did the idea of a "consumer society" begin?

answers.text: at the turn of the 19th century.

qas.question: What social group grew as a result of the industrial revolution?
What is one explanation for the rise of retail stores in earlier history?
What group of people were suddenly free to go shopping without fears of being judged or reprimanded?

plausible_answers.text: at the turn of the 19th century

qas.question: When didn't the idea of a "consumer society" begin?
What social group shrank as a result of the industrial revolution?
What is one explanation for the fall of retail stores in earlier history?
What group of people were suddenly no longer free to go shopping with fears of being judged or reprimanded?

context: The origins of the department store lay in the growth of the conspicuous consumer society <a0_0><b5_0>at the turn of the 19th century<b5_0/>.<a0_0/> As the Industrial Revolution accelerated economy expansion, <a1_0><b6_0>the affluent middle-class<b6_0/><a1_0/> grew in size and wealth. This <a3_0><b8_0>urbanized social group<b8_0/><a3_0/>, sharing a culture of consumption and changing fashion, was the catalyst for the retail revolution. As rising prosperity and social mobility increased the number of people, especially <a4_0><b9_0>women<b9_0/><a4_0/> (who found they could shop unaccompanied at department stores without damaging their reputation), with disposable income in the late Georgian period, window shopping was transformed into a leisure activity and <a2_0><b7_0>entrepreneurs<b7_0/><a2_0/>, like the potter Josiah Wedgwood, pioneered the use of marketing techniques to influence the prevailing tastes and preferences of society.
